entry.title: Armenian law enforcement raids fringe group after police station attack

media:group.media:title: Armenian law enforcement raids fringe group after police station attack
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenian police found additional weapons in raids at homes of members and the offices of a fringe group that may be connected to a police station attack over the weekend. üìç A Russian government spokesperson called on Armenia to show ‚Äúpolitical will to continue developing relations‚Äù as ties between the two countries continue to fray. üìç Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan called on Turkey to implement a preliminary agreement reached two years ago to partially reopen its long-closed border with Armenia.
Credits: Ruptly

entry.title: Laurence Broers: Sustainable peace is ‚Äòbeyond the high table and a piece of paper‚Äô

media:group.media:title: Laurence Broers: Sustainable peace is ‚Äòbeyond the high table and a piece of paper‚Äô
media:group.media:description:
Laurence Broers, associate fellow at Chatham House‚Äôs Russia and Eurasia Programme, sits down with CivilNet‚Äôs Karen Harutyunyan to speak about the developments in the region since the 2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war. Laurence discusses regional geopolitics, Western mediation efforts, the bilateral negotiation track, and Russia‚Äôs role. Even weakened, Russia will remain a tremendously powerful player in the South Caucasus, Laurence says.
Earlier last week, Laurence delivered a speech at a conference in Yerevan titled ‚ÄúThe South Caucasus: Trends and prospects in the context of the war in Ukraine,‚Äù organized by the Caucasus Institute.
0:00 Why did Russia fail to enforce the full implementation of the November 9 agreement? 5:13 How could the situation over Karabakh have evolved if Armenia and Azerbaijan had kept to the deal? 9:57 Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine and Azerbaijan‚Äôs new opportunities for coercive diplomacy. 12:07 ‚ÄòPutin wants to punish Pashinyan‚Äô 14:32 Can the West and Russia compartmentalize the Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict? 22:22 Armenia and Azerbaijan are in post-mediation phase. 27:00 Why couldn‚Äôt the West prevent ethnic cleansing in Karabakh? 31:28 What could happen in the Caucasus if Russia wins the war in Ukraine?

entry.title: Georgia announces support for Armenia‚Äôs territorial integrity

media:group.media:title: Georgia announces support for Armenia‚Äôs territorial integrity
media:group.media:description:
üìç Two men were injured and a third detained after they attempted to break into a police precinct building in Yerevan. üìç On his first visit to Yerevan, new Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Kobakhidze expressed gratitude that Yerevan recognizes Georgia‚Äôs territorial integrity, and that in turn declared Tbilisi unreservedly supports Armenia‚Äôs territorial integrity. üìç Also Watch: CivilNet‚Äôs team speaks to residents in Tavush as Azerbaijan demands border concessions there https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bbclKd__S88 üìç Also Watch: Weekly Armenian Business Digest https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vIdimvvU1zc

Turkey is not impartial in the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan and supports Azerbaijan based on pragmatic calculations, according to Mustafa Aydin, professor of international relations at Turkey's Kadir Has University. Sitting down with CivilNet‚Äôs Georgi Mirzabekyan, Aydin notes that, for Turkey to be more influential in the region, it needs to have closer ties with Armenia and Georgia. This helps explain the arrangement of powers in the South Caucasus and the convergence and divergence of major powers‚Äô interests here. The Turkish professor was in Yerevan to participate in the ‚ÄúThe South Caucasus: Trends and prospects in the context of the war in Ukraine‚Äù conference.

entry.title: Tavush border village residents want their lands back from Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: Tavush border village residents want their lands back from Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
Four years after the military clashes in the Tavush-Tovuz region of the Armenian-Azerbaijani border, there are renewed concerns in the northeastern part of Armenia regarding potential aggression from Azerbaijan. As efforts to reach a normalization deal continue to stall, Baku has demanded that Yerevan relinquish control of four out of eight villages, which were previously inhabited by Azerbaijanis but are located within the Republic of Armenia. Meanwhile, Armenia‚Äôs demands for the return of segments of lands belonging to 31 villages continue to be ignored.
